awd_titl_txt: NEB: Developing a Graphene Spin Computer: Materials, Nano-Devices, Modeling, and Circuits
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is awarded under the Nanoelectronics for 2020 and Beyond competition, with support by multiple Directorates and Divisions at the National Science Foundation as well as by the Nanoelectronics Research Initiative of the Semiconductor Research Corporation.

****Technical Abstract.****
Recent breakthroughs by the PI/co-PIs on the efficient injection and transport of spin in graphene at room temperature and the design of novel magnetologic gates (MLG) and circuits enable a new paradigm for computing that utilizes the electron spin to store and process information. In this project, graphene-based MLG devices and circuits will be designed and demonstrated through a concerted interdisciplinary effort that includes experiment (materials/devices/circuits), theory, and circuit design and simulation. A successful implementation of the MLG will lead to high-speed, low-power information processing by enabling computing architectures that integrate logic and memory to avoid the von Neumann bottleneck which hampers performance in modern computers. The interdisciplinary team will work together to tackle the three critical challenges for developing a functional MLG circuit: (1) to understand and optimize the spin injection and transport in graphene, (2) to develop a high-speed, low-power method of switching the FM electrodes that is compatible with graphene, (3) to design and implement CMOS-compatible MLG circuits. The program will promote diversity within the US technical workforce and prepare valuable specialists for the US electronics and magnetic recording industries.

****Non-technical abstract****
As silicon electronics approaches its physical limits, there is a need to explore alternative technologies in order to develop faster computers that consume less energy. This project will develop a new paradigm for computing that exploits the magnetic poles (i.e. "spin") of electrons traveling inside a one-atom-thick layer of carbon known as graphene (recipient of the 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics). A long-term advantage will be to greatly accelerate computing applications that involve large amounts of data, such as database searching, data compression, and image recognition, which are important for homeland security. Technically, this will be accomplished by developing a new electronic device called a "magnetologic gate," which will serve as the building block for circuits that combine the functions of microprocessors (for decision making) and hard drives (for information storage) into a single chip. The team consists of the physicists, material scientists, and electrical engineers who have pioneered the key scientific breakthroughs that enable this future technology. The program will promote diversity within the US technical workforce and prepare valuable specialists for the US electronics and magnetic recording industries.

Intellectual Merit:

The discovery of large resistance changes by an applied magnetic field (magnetoresistance) has enabled a thousand-fold increase in the information storage density of computer hard-drives over the last decade and was recognized by the 2007 Nobel Prize in Physics. However, this is only the tip of the iceberg. The discovery of graphene (single atomic sheet of carbon) and its excellent spin transport properties at room temperature opens up the possibility for much more. A versatile control of electron spin and magnetism in graphene and graphene-based nanostructures may have a much broader impact leading to new multifunctional devices that seamlessly integrate memory and logic for low-power/high-speed operation. Our team effort focused on laying the groundwork for such applications of graphene-based spintronics through (1) design of unique spintronic circuits and magnetologic gates, (2) experimental demonstration and theoretical analysis of desired functionalities, (3) exploration of new physics that enables more advanced device designs.

The major project outcomes are:

* We designed and simulated spintronic circuits for efficient searching, based on integration of memory and logic functions. These circuits are based on a universal magnetologic gate consisting of five ferromagnetic (FM) electrodes connected by a graphene sheet, where the magnetization directions (that is, the orientation of the north and south poles of the FM) determine the input and output of the logic gate.

* We demonstrated the first magnetologic gate operation using a graphene spin channel. Specifically, we achieved an exclusive-or (XOR) logic gate operation by processing the inputs from two FM electrodes and reading the output though a third FM. The logic operation was achieved through electrical tuning of spin injection efficiency and serves as a building block for the five electrode universal gate.

* We demonstrated energy efficient magnetization switching mechanisms based on spin Hall torque. These are critical for implementing spintronic circuits because they provide an efficient means for writing and reading of the input and output states of the magnetologic gates.

* We performed computational modeling of the FM-graphene junction, which is the most important building block for magnetologic gates. This is crucial for understanding the key processes utilizing ferromagnets to create and detect electronic spin polarization in graphene. These calculations are important not only for magnetologic gates, but also for other potential spintronic applications.

* We developed a theory for impurity-driven effects in tunnel barriers that connect FM spin injectors to nonmagnetic spin channels (semiconductors, graphene). Calculations reveal a new impurity-resonance-tunneling magnetoresistance effect that needs to be taken into account when analyzing experiments.

* We developed a theory for the intrinsic spin relaxation in graphene due to the electron-phonon interaction. We found that spin lifetime is suppressed by scattering off flexural phonons (out-of-plane motion of the atoms). Thus, we predicted that spin lifetime could be increased by the application of strain or by sandwiching graphene between two rigid insulators to reduce the out-of-plane motion.

* We developed a quantum theory for magnetization dynamics, which becomes significant as the magnetic electrodes are reduced in size. We investigated magnetization dynamics generated by electrical currents via spin torque, which is the method utilized for writing magnetic data into the magnetologic gates. We further extended the theory to explore new physics of optical excitation of magnetization dynamics, which provides an alternative method for writing magnetic data bits.
